definition:
For an indeterminate $q$ and integers $n \ge m \ge 0$ we define the
following:

\(a) $(m)_q = q^{m-1} + q^{m-2} + \cdots + 1$ for $m>0$,

\(b) $(m!)_q = (m)_q (m-1)_q \cdots (1)_q$ for $m>0$, and $(0!)_q = 1$,

\(c) ${n \choose m}_q = \frac{(n!)_q}{(m!)_q ((n-m)!)_q}$. If $m>n$ then
we define ${n \choose m}_q=0$.

The expressions ${n \choose m}_q$ are called [*$q$-binomial
coefficients*]{} or [*Gaussian polynomials*]{}.

Note: if we replace $q$ with 1, then we obtain the familiar integers,
factorials, and binomial coefficients. Specifically,

\(a) $(m)_1 = m$,

\(b) $(m!)_1 = m!$,

\(c) ${n \choose m}_1 = {n \choose m}$.

\(d) ${m \choose m}_q=1$.
